question: Which of the following describes the modulation process in a transmitting station?
options: The process of converting analog signals into digital bits
The modification of carrier signal parameters such as amplitude, frequency, or phase based on the symbol
The encryption of source data to ensure privacy
The removal of noise from the air interface
correct_answers: The modification of carrier signal parameters such as amplitude, frequency, or phase based on the symbol

question: What is a primary disadvantage of the Amplitude Shift Keying (ASK) modulation technique?
options: It requires excessive bandwidth
It is highly complex to implement
It is susceptible to sudden gain changes
It cannot represent binary 0
correct_answers: It is susceptible to sudden gain changes

question: Which of the following are characteristics of Quadrature Phase Shift Keying (QPSK)?
options: It uses four signal states to transmit two bits per symbol
It requires more bandwidth than BPSK
It is used in UMTS and IEEE 802.11 networks
It utilizes an In-Phase (I) and Quadrature-Phase (Q) axis
correct_answers: It uses four signal states to transmit two bits per symbol
It is used in UMTS and IEEE 802.11 networks
It utilizes an In-Phase (I) and Quadrature-Phase (Q) axis

question: As the number of bits per symbol increases in higher-order modulation like 256QAM, what is the trade-off?
options: The signal becomes less susceptible to noise
The Bit Error Rate (BER) decreases
The susceptibility to noise and interference increases
The complexity of the carrier oscillator decreases
correct_answers: The susceptibility to noise and interference increases

question: In a Frequency Division Duplex (FDD) system, how are the forward and reverse links managed?
options: They use the same frequency but different time slots
The forward link frequency (F1) and reverse link frequency (F2) are different
Signals are transmitted sequentially like a ping-pong game
They share a single frequency without any separation
correct_answers: The forward link frequency (F1) and reverse link frequency (F2) are different

question: What is the primary characteristic of Time Division Duplex (TDD)?
options: It requires two separate frequency bands
Forward and reverse links use the same frequency
Signals are transmitted continuously in parallel
It is immune to propagation delay
correct_answers: Forward and reverse links use the same frequency

question: Match the MAC protocol category to its specific example or description.
options: TDMA, FDMA
Aloha, CSMA/CD
Token Ring, Polling
Divides channel into exclusive pieces

question: What is the maximum theoretical throughput of Pure (unslotted) ALOHA?
In Slotted ALOHA, what action is taken if a collision occurs?
options: The packet is discarded immediately
The node retransmits in the current slot
The node retransmits in future slots with probability p
The system switches to FDMA mode
correct_answers: The node retransmits in future slots with probability p

question: Which scenario defines the 'Hidden Terminal Problem'?
options: Nodes A and C can hear each other but not Node B
Node B is out of range of all other nodes
Nodes A and C cannot hear each other but their transmissions collide at Node B
A node is physically hidden behind a mountain and cannot transmit at all
correct_answers: Nodes A and C cannot hear each other but their transmissions collide at Node B

question: What is the specific sequence used to solve the Hidden Terminal Problem in CSMA/CA?
options: ACK -> DATA
RTS (Request-to-Send) -> CTS (Clear-to-Send)
SYN -> SYN-ACK
POLL -> RESPONSE
correct_answers: RTS (Request-to-Send) -> CTS (Clear-to-Send)

question: Why are 'guard bands' necessary in Frequency Division Multiplexing (FDM)?
options: To increase the total bandwidth
To prevent overlapping and interference between adjacent carrier frequencies
To provide a path for the clock synchronization signal
To encrypt the individual channels
correct_answers: To prevent overlapping and interference between adjacent carrier frequencies

question: According to the slides, what is the primary distinction between multiplexing and multiple access?
options: There is no distinction; they are identical terms
Multiplexing is a Link Layer function; Multiple Access is Physical Layer
Multiplexing is a Physical Layer function; Multiple Access is a Link Layer function
Multiplexing only uses time; Multiple Access only uses codes
correct_answers: Multiplexing is a Physical Layer function; Multiple Access is a Link Layer function

question: Which feature is supported by TDMA but not by standard static TDM?
options: Synchronized switches
Alternating patterns
Demand assignment (assignment of slots changes over time)
Exclusive frequency use
correct_answers: Demand assignment (assignment of slots changes over time)

question: In the GSM TDM example, what is the duration of one 'guard time'?
options: 4.615 msec
576.9 µsec
30.5 µsec (approx. 8.25 bits)
26 bits
correct_answers: 30.5 µsec (approx. 8.25 bits)

question: Which of the following are standard modulation schemes for 5G Uplink according to 3GPP?
options: π/2-BPSK
QPSK
1024QAM
256QAM
correct_answers: π/2-BPSK
QPSK
256QAM

question: In Binary Phase Shift Keying (BPSK), how is a 'binary 0' represented mathematically?
options: A cos(2πfct)
0 (absence of carrier)
-A cos(2πfct)
A cos(2πfct + π/2)
correct_answers: -A cos(2πfct)

question: How does Differential PSK (DPSK) determine the phase of the current bit?
options: By using a fixed absolute reference phase
By shifting phase with reference to the previous bit
By checking the amplitude of the signal
By using a different carrier frequency
correct_answers: By shifting phase with reference to the previous bit

question: What is the primary goal of Medium Access Control (MAC) protocols?
options: To maximize transmit power
To prevent collisions while maximizing throughput and minimizing delay
To encrypt all wireless traffic
To increase the number of base stations
correct_answers: To prevent collisions while maximizing throughput and minimizing delay

question: Which type of MAC protocol is described as 'efficient at low load' because a single node can fully utilize the channel?
options: Channel partitioning
Static allocation
Random access
Token-based
correct_answers: Random access

question: What is the primary purpose of Spread Spectrum technology?
options: To reduce the bandwidth of the signal for efficiency
To spread information over a wider bandwidth to prevent jamming and interception
To increase the power levels of the transmitter
To eliminate the need for channel encoding
correct_answers: To spread information over a wider bandwidth to prevent jamming and interception

question: In Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS), what is a 'chip'?
options: A small piece of hardware in the base station
A bit in the pseudonoise (PN) sequence used for spreading
The final output data bit after decoding
A frequency channel in a hopping sequence
correct_answers: A bit in the pseudonoise (PN) sequence used for spreading

question: In Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA), how is a '0' bit transmitted by User A if their code is <c1, c2, c3, c4, c5, c6>?
options: By sending the code as a chip pattern
By sending the complement of the code: <-c1, -c2, -c3, -c4, -c5, -c6>
By sending all zeros
By changing the hopping frequency
correct_answers: By sending the complement of the code: <-c1, -c2, -c3, -c4, -c5, -c6>

question: In the CDMA example, what happens when a receiver using User A's code attempts to decode a signal sent by User B?
options: It results in a value of 6, indicating a '1' bit
It results in a value of -6, indicating a '0' bit
It results in a value of 0, meaning the unwanted signal is ignored
The system crashes due to interference
correct_answers: It results in a value of 0, meaning the unwanted signal is ignored

question: What is the primary function of a RAKE receiver?
options: To prevent frequency hopping
To recover and combine signals from multiple paths in a multipath environment
To increase the transmission power of the mobile unit
To block all signals except the dominant one
correct_answers: To recover and combine signals from multiple paths in a multipath environment

question: Which of the following are listed as advantages of CDMA?
options: Multipath fading is substantially reduced
No absolute limit on the number of users
Easy addition of more users
Decreased battery life for mobile units
correct_answers: Multipath fading is substantially reduced
No absolute limit on the number of users
Easy addition of more users

question: How does Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplex (OFDM) achieve high-speed data transmission?
options: By using a single high-power carrier frequency
By dividing a channel into multiple orthogonal subchannels and sending parallel low-speed data
By increasing the bandwidth of a single serial stream
By eliminating the need for a modulator
correct_answers: By dividing a channel into multiple orthogonal subchannels and sending parallel low-speed data

question: What is the theoretical bandwidth saving of Orthogonal multicarrier techniques compared to conventional multicarrier techniques?
Match the OFDM-related issue to its definition.
options: Occurs when subcarriers are out of phase
Interference because frequencies are spaced closely

correct_answers.A: Occurs when subcarriers are out of phase
correct_answers.B: Interference because frequencies are spaced closely

question: What is a key difference between OFDM and OFDMA?
options: OFDM uses codes, OFDMA uses time
OFDM subcarriers are for a single data source; OFDMA allows different users to use subsets of carriers
OFDMA is only used in 2G networks
OFDM is contention-based, OFDMA is collision-free
correct_answers: OFDM subcarriers are for a single data source; OFDMA allows different users to use subsets of carriers

question: What is the 'frequency reuse' principle in cellular networks?
options: Adjacent cells always use the same frequency band
Distant cells can reuse the same frequency band to avoid interference
Every cell in a city uses the exact same frequency simultaneously
Frequencies are only used once and never repeated in the network
correct_answers: Distant cells can reuse the same frequency band to avoid interference

question: Which of the following are benefits of frequency reuse?
options: Solves spectral congestion and increases user capacity
Enables high capacity in a limited spectrum allocation
Requires high-power transmitters to cover the entire city
Enables the use of low power transmitters
correct_answers: Solves spectral congestion and increases user capacity
Enables high capacity in a limited spectrum allocation
Enables the use of low power transmitters

question: According to the frequency reuse formula $N = i^2 + j^2 + ij$, which of the following are possible cluster sizes (N)?
options: Only prime numbers

question: What is 'Cell Splitting'?
options: A bug in the network that disconnects users
The process of dividing an existing cell into multiple smaller cells with their own base stations
Sharing a single mobile device between two users
Allocating half a frequency to one user and half to another
correct_answers: The process of dividing an existing cell into multiple smaller cells with their own base stations

question: Match the cellular generation to its specific Access Network component.
options: GERAN
UTRAN
E-UTRAN
NG-RAN

question: What is the difference between a Hard Handover (HHO) and a Soft Handover (SHO)?
options: HHO is 'make before break'; SHO is 'break before make'
HHO is 'break before make'; SHO is 'make before break'
HHO only happens in 5G; SHO is for 2G
There is no difference
correct_answers: HHO is 'break before make'; SHO is 'make before break'

question: Which handover performance metric represents the probability that a new call is blocked due to high load on BS traffic capacity?
options: Call dropping probability
Call blocking probability
Interruption duration
Handover delay
correct_answers: Call blocking probability

question: Why is it desirable to minimize transmission power in mobile units?
options: To maximize co-channel interference
To minimize impact on health and battery life
To increase the complexity of the base station
To reduce the signal-to-noise ratio
correct_answers: To minimize impact on health and battery life

question: In 'Closed-loop power control', what metrics are used to adjust signal strength?
options: Received SNR (Signal-to-Noise Ratio)
Bit Error Rate (BER)
Battery temperature
Received packet error rate
correct_answers: Received SNR (Signal-to-Noise Ratio)
Bit Error Rate (BER)
Received packet error rate

question: Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS) often uses which modulation technique for spreading as shown in the spectrum diagrams?
options: Frequency Modulation (FM)
Binary Phase Shift Keying (BPSK)
Amplitude Modulation (AM)
Morse Code
correct_answers: Binary Phase Shift Keying (BPSK)
